etymologies: late Middle English. From Anglo-Norman regratier, Anglo-Norman and Middle French regrater (French regratter) to buy up (commodities, especially food) in order to resell at a profit in the same or a neighbouring market, further etymology uncertain and disputed. Compare post-classical Latin regratare

definitions: To buy up (commodities, especially food) in order to resell at a profit in the same or a neighbouring market.
To sell on (commodities so bought) at a profit.
